solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Trapezium (2) + Area of Triangle (3) + Area of Triangle (4) + Area of Triangle (5)
\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 30 \times 31 + \frac 12 \times 68.5 \times 46 + \frac 12 \times 37.5 \times 22.5 + \frac 12 \times 30 \times 37.5 + \frac 12 \times 61 \times 30\)
\(=4164.875 cm^2\)

\(= \frac 12 (24 + 32)(16) \times 2\)

solution.text:
Volume = Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder
\(=\pi \times {r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi \times {r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(=10182.86 - 8045.71\)
\(=2137.14 cm^3\)

\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2 (\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2564.57 cm^2\)

Volume of a Cube: \(side^3\)

solution.text:
Volume of pipe=Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder
\(= \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= \pi (18)^2 \times 40 - \pi(16)^2 \times 40\)
= 8548.57\( cm^3\)
\(Mass = Volume \times Density\)
\(\Rightarrow Mass = 8548.57 cm^3 \times \frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\)
= 73517.71 g

content.text: The inner diameter of a metallic tube is 16 cm. The thickness of the rim is 2 cm and the length is 40 cm. If the density of the metal is \(\frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\), what is the mass of the pipe?

hint.text: Volume = Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 135 \times 38 + \frac 12 \times 55\times(135 + 105)\)
\(= 11730 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 5 km/hr = 5000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 11730 \times 5000 = 58650000 m^3/hr\)
= 58650 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 58650\)
= 9853200 megalitres

content.text: The Vashishti river flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. You measure the dimensions of the river and find that a = 135 m, b = 105 m, c = 38 m and d= 93 m. The river flows at a constant rate of 5 km / hr. What volume of water (in megalitres) flows into the sea over the course of a week? Note that 1 megalitre = 1000000 litres

The volume of the cylindrical pool \(= \pi \times (\frac d2)^2 \times (h) m^3 = \pi \times (\frac{18}2)^2 \times (1) m^3\)
\(= 254571.43\) L

content.text: Your school is building a cylindrical swimming pool with a diameter of 18 metres and a depth of 1 metres. How much water (in litres) will they require to completely fill the pool?

hint.text: Volume of a cylindrical container = \(\pi \times r^2 \times h\) and \(1m^3 = 1000L\)

solution.text:
The volume of the tank \(= 34 cm \times 46 cm \times 36 cm \)= 56304
Rate of flow into the tank = 8L/minute = 8000\(cm^3\)/minute
Therefore, time taken to fill tank completely \(= \frac {56304}{8000} \)= 7.038 minutes

content.text: Rajiv likes to make 3D shapes from paper. Yesterday, he started with a rectangular piece of paper of length 24 cm and breadth 14 cm. He then rolled the paper into a cylinder so that the cylinder is now 24 cm long. What is the volume of the air inside the cylinder so formed?

solution.text:
Curved Surface area of the roller \(= 2 \pi rh = 2\pi \times \frac {10}2 \times 39 = 1225.71 cm^2\)
Area covered per rotation \(= 1225.71 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area painted in 54 rolls \(= 1225.71 \times 54 = 66188.57 cm^2\)

content.text: Last Monday, Ram painted a rectangular wall with a cylindrical paint roller. The length of the roller is 39 cm and its diameter is 10 cm. While painting, the roller rolled over 54 times completely. What surface area did Ram paint?

hint.text: How much area does the roller cover in one rotation?

solution.text:
Total surface area \(= 6 \times 24^2 = 6 (side)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Length of side = \((\frac {3456}{6})^{\frac 12} = 24 cm\)

content.text: A closed box in the shape of a cube has a total outer surface area of 3456 \(cm^2.\) What is the length of its side in centimetres?

hint.text: Remember that surface area of a cube is \(6 \times side^2\)

solution.text:
If the height is doubled :
V \(= \pi r^2\times h\)
\({V_ {new}} = \pi r^2 \times(2h) = 2\pi r^2 \times h = 2V\)
Therefore, the volume will double

content.text: If the height is doubled:

solution.text:
If the radius is doubled :
V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\({V_ {new}} = \pi (2r)^2h = 4\pi r^2h = 4V\)
Therefore, the volume will quadruple

content.text: If the radius is doubled:

solution.text:
If the radius is halved :
V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\(V_ {new} = \pi (\frac r2)^2h = \frac V4\)
Therefore, the volume will quarter

hint.text: Volume of a cube = \(side^3\)

solution.text:
Volume of the brick wall \(= 12 m \times 2 m \times 0.5 m = 12 m^3\)
Volume of one brick \(= 20 cm \times 10 cm \times 5 cm = 1000 cm^3\)
\(1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3\)
Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 12 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 12000\)

content.text: Anjali is building a brick wall which is 12 m long, 2m tall and 50cm wide. Each brick is 20cm long, 10 cm wide and 5 cm tall. How many bricks will Anjali need to buy?

hint.text: Start by calculating the volume of the entire brick wall

solution.text:
Total surface area of all the cubes \(= 5 \times 6 \times 1.6^2 = 76.8 cm^2\)
Area of each face =\(1.6^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 76.8 - 25.6 = 51.2 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 18 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(51.2 \times 18\)
= Rs. 921.6

content.text: Five cubes of edge 1.6 cm each are placed side by side and stuck together as shown. The cost of painting is Rs 18 per \(cm^2\). What is the cost of painting the outer surface of the entire object?

hint.text: Count the number of faces that are outward facing

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 7542.86 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {16}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {16}{2} - 6)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {16}2)^2-\pi (\frac {16}2 - m)^2}\)
= 40 cm

content.text: A metallic tube, 50 cm long, has a thickness of 4 cm and an outer diameter of 16 cm. It is melted and made into another tube of thickness 6 cm with the same outer diameter. No material is wasted. What is the length of the new tube?

hint.text: Since no material is wasted, the volumes of both tubes are exactly equal

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 66 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{66}{\pi} = 21 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 66 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 66 + 21\)
= 27.6 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(66 cm^2\). You then cut a straight slice from the cake (as shown below) such that the volume of the slice is exactly \(\frac {1}{10}\) of the volume of the cake. What surface area of your slice has no icing?

hint.text: Think about your slice as a separate object. What faces do not have icing?

solution.text:
Volume of the large cube \(= 32^3 cm^3\)
Volume of the small cube \(= 16^3 cm^3\).
Therefore, number of cubes that can be cut \(= \frac {32^3}{16^3} = 8\) cubes

content.text: A cube has an edge measuring 32 cm. Find the number of cubes of edge 16 cm that can be cut off from it.

hint.text: Find the volume of the large cube and compare it to the volume of the smaller cube

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 11^2 \times 29 = 11028.29 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 11028.29 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 34 \times 17 \times h = 11028.29 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {11028.29}{34 \times 17} = 19.08\)
The new cuboid is 19.08 cm tall

content.text: A metal cylinder of height 29 cm and radius 11 cm is melted and reshaped into a cuboid of length 34 cm and breadth 17 cm. No metal was wasted during this process. How tall is the new cuboid?

hint.text: If no metal is wasted, both objects will have the same volume.

solution.text:
Rise in water level = 1.5 metres = 150 cm = h
Area of base = Area of Triangle = \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times side^2 = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 45^2\)
=\(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 2025 cm^2\)
Therefore, volume of water added = Area of base \(\times\) Rise in water Level
=131371.88 \(cm^3\)
Since 1L =\(1000cm^3\)
Volume of water added = 131.37 L

content.text: The water tank in Rekha’s house has a base in the shape of an equilateral triangle with each side measuring 45 cm. It is filled with water till a height of 3 metres. Rise of water level = h = 13 cm
Therefore, volume of rain water harvested \(= 15400 \times 13 = 200200 cm^3\)
1 L \(= 1000cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow\)Volume of rain water harvested \(= 200.2 L\)

content.text: You have set up a rain-water harvesting system at your home. A cylindrical container with a radius of 7 dm collects rain-water from your roof. Cost of painting the box = Rs. 2.6 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the box = \(1630 \times 2.6\)
= Rs. 4238

content.text: Latika needs to paint a rectangular box from the outside. The cost of painting the box is Rs. 2.6 per \(cm^2.\) If the dimensions of the box are \(28 cm \times 13 cm \times 11 cm\), what is the total cost of painting the box?

solution.text:
Area of tin sheet required for 1 box = Surface area of one box
\(= 2 (7 \times 3 + 3 \times 7 + 7 \times 7) = 182 cm^2\)
Therefore, area of tin required for 9 boxes \(= 182 \times 9\)
\(= 1638 cm^2\)

content.text: You need to create a tin box of dimensions \(7 cm \times 3 cm \times 7 cm.\) What is the area of a sheet of tin required to make 9 such tins?

content.text: The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 416 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(416 m^2\)
Therefore, \(416 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{416}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{4}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 2 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid?

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 4158\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{4158}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{4158}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {4158\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 21 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 10.5 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 14553 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 4158 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder

solution.text:
Given the area \(= \frac 12 \times Width \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)
\(= \frac 12 \times 25 \times (15 +\) River Side Length\()\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{937.5}{12.5} - 15\)
\(= 60 m\)

hint.text: The area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times Height \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)

solution.text: Volume = Area of base \(\times\) height \(= 64 cm^2 \times 15 cm = 960 cm^3\)

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 7392 m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 22 \times 14 = 308 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 240000

content.text: The area of your school library floor is \(7392 m^2\). You are asked to use tiles in the shape of a parallelogram with a base of 22 cm and a height of 14 cm to cover the floor. How many such tiles will you need to purchase? You can break the tiles in any way to cover the entire floor.

hint.text: Start by finding the area of each tile.

solution.text:
Area of Garden = Area of Plot - Area of the House
\(= ab - cd\)
\(= (4180 - 48(11)) m^2\)
\(=3652 m^2\)

content.text: Kshitij is looking to landscape his garden. He made a diagram of his house (grey colour) but forgot to mention the exact dimensions of the garden area. You are the engineer in charge of the project. Can you use the information given below to calculate the area of the garden? a = 110 m, b = 38 m, c = 48 m, d = 11 m

hint.text: Try subtracting areas to find the right answer

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\pi \times \frac{20}2 \times 14 + 2 \pi \times \frac{10}2 \times 14 + 2\pi({\frac{20}2}^2 - {\frac{10}2}^2)\)
= 1791.43\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 1791.43 \times 0.2\)
= Rs. 358.29

content.text: A cylindrical pipe has an outer diameter of 20 cm and an inner diameter of 10 cm. Its length is 14 cm. It needs to be painted on its outer and inner surfaces, as well as the rims. The cost of painting the pipe is Rs. 0.2 per \(cm^2\). What is the total cost of painting the pipe?

hint.text: Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 4412.57 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (8)^2 \times 36 - \pi (8-x)^2 \times 36\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{36\pi}=8^2 - (8-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (8-x)^2 = 64 - \frac{V}{36\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 8 - 5\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

content.text: The volume of a metallic cylinder pipe is 4412.57 cubic centimetres. Its length is 36 cm and its external radius is 8 cm. Find its thickness
